awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Nicole R. Looper is "Uniformity in families of algebraic dynamical systems". The host institution for the fellowship is the Cambridge University, UK, and the sponsoring scientist is Holly Krieger.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI worked on several problems in arithmetic dynamics and adjacent areas. 

  1. The PI addressed the Uniform Boundedness Conjecture of Morton and Silverman across all degree d polynomials over a given number field, conditional on a standard conjecture in arithmetic geometry. For many families of polynomials over function fields, analogous results were shown to hold unconditionally. The PI also cast these results in the broader framework of a theorem on points of small canonical height.
  2. Along with Silverman and Wilms, the PI proved a uniform quantitative Manin--Mumford and Bogomolov result for higher genus curves over one-variable function fields. 
  3. For polynomials over a number field K having a finite superattracting point and at least one place of bad reduction, the PI proved a finiteness result for the number of preperiodic points contained in the maximal abelian extension of K.
  4. Along with Silverman, the PI proved a Lehmer-style lower bound on the canonical height for abelian surfaces over a function field.
  5. Along with Juul, Krieger, and Mavraki, the PI proved a dynamical Shafarevich theorem for endomorphisms of projective space over a number field. 

The PI participated in the following outreach and service during the funding period in question.

  1. The PI gave approximately 30 research talks in various parts of Europe, Canada, and the US.
  2. The PI co-organized several conferences, such as the 2020 JMM Special Session in Arithmetic Dynamics. 
  3. The PI participated in seminar organization and outreach in the math department at Brown University.
